description:
What an experience! 19 courses of heaven!!!

I came here with a group of 7 and were seated at the counter. It was so much fun seeing everything being plated with such patience and attention to detail. 

The creativity of each dish and flavors went above my expectations. And I can see why. One of the only Mexican restaurants with two Michelin stars speaks for itself.

I've never been much of a bean person but their bean dish with creme fraîche, caviar & gold flakes was phenomenal. Let's not forget about the esquite with lobster butter & lobster! Literally would kill to have this everyday of my life. 

The wine pairing complimented each dish, flavor and wine itself.

This place is a must if you haven't been yet. I can't wait to go back and experience new dishes soon.
author: Nancy L.

description:
I had the chance to experience Californios recently and overall it was a great balance of Mexican flavors with California ingredients and touches. There were 19 courses, and due to the events of the day I did not arrive hungry, unfortunately. I still got through all of the courses, but I am sure I would've enjoyed them more if my stomach was a bit more empty. Still, everything was quite enjoyable.

The most delicious stands out for me were the yuca taco with uni, the soup with saffron and gooseberry, the barbacoa with wagyu beef cheek, and the plantain bread. The uni was very creamy, and the soup was warming and bursting with comforting flavors. I could eat the plantain bread all day.
author: James K.

description:
This place is worth splurging on. Chef Val Cantu sure knows what he is doing here and has assembled a great team in creating and awesome eating experience.

Some of the highlights of the meal were the mushroom tacos, corn mousse, and the bean dish. I posted the tasting menu photo to help. The chefs were all very knowledgeable and friendly to chat with and I learned a lot about the process of making specific dishes and really helped me appreciate the time and effort they put into each one! 

I definitely recommend sitting at the chef's table. The other seating is a lot darker whereas the chef's table is well lit and you get to see all the action!

Another recommendation is that if you plan on drinking, just go for the drink pairing which will cost an additional $120pp but is well worth it since I got two drinks and the tab already ran me $60 more dollars.

Fun experience and would recommend!!
author: Linda X.

description:
AMAZING EXPERIENCE! It is definitely on the pricier side but the overall experience is so worth it. 3 hours and 16 course meal. You will be full haha and you have the option to pair it with drinks. Without the drink pairing, it's about $177/per person. 

You will not be disappointed. Great service and amazing food!
author: Jenn L.

description:
It's worth shouting from the roof tops about the creativity of this chef and team. Not to mention, the out-of-this-world flawless service.

Californios has perfected the art of timing, presentation, unique flavor combinations that is becoming harder and harder to find in most Michelin-star restaurants. Comparing to other experiences over the years with others that have made the list, you can almost always find the service lacking or under-compensating in some form. By that I mean friendly, humble people who pay attention to detail. 

There was barely a moment that passed once a dish was finished or a glass was drained that the next form of cutlery or wine pairing was out to dazzle. From wiping the wine label clean for a better visual of the wine specifics to allowing us to "pick our weapon" for the lamb course, the staff made it feel like I was part of an exceptional experience.

Modern looks and music, no pretenses or fuss with stuffy decor. You'll go the first 7-8 courses without silverware, if you can believe it! It's precisely the way you should want every Michelin-star to behave.

Moving onto the culinary excursions and the wine itself; the pairings were unusually delightful. A sour beer served alongside a rich broth? More please. Grilled asparagus to mate with a difficult Grüner Veltliner? Who knew there was such a match in heaven! (P.s. the bright green notes together tasted like Sweet Tarts or Gummie Bears and highly recommend you try this combo at home with dinner guests!). The famous tres frijoles is as stellar as they say and I still can't stop talking about my first sourdough tortilla with pigeon and mole. You stole my heart with a Rioja Tempranillo to go with the most exceptionally rare lamb chop and now all I want to do is go back to Spain.

My only advice, make sure you go wash your hands after the smoked hen-of-the-woods mushroom taco. It was a bit too smoky for my tastes and it will overpower the next few dishes that you'll eat with your hands.

Full disclosure: I had a non-seafood adjustment and they were wonderfully accommodating. All you have to do is call advance after you book your reservation online if you have any allergies.
author: Alita M.

description:
Several of my friends have recommended Californios and even with my high expectations, I was blown away. The 3 hour meal consisted of about 16 courses, each meticulously created and wonderfully delicious. And that is no small feat. Often at upscale restaurants, I find that there are a couple of courses that just don't taste good even if they look great and a couple of courses where the plating is pretty but insanely impractical for eating. Every single course here was fantastic.

Since there are so many plates, expect the bites at the beginning to be very small. It does take a while before you start to feel full so I recommend making an early dinner reservation like we did. 

My favorite of the night was one of the first - a mushroom taco on a handmade blue corn tortilla. The earthiness from the mushroom medley was beautiful and quite "meaty." This was one of three taco presentations during the meal. Halfway through, we were served a delicate hard-shelled uni taco. Yum! And toward the end, we had a make-you-own-squab-taco course.

Californios celebrates Mexican heritage and interprets it in its own way. One of the desserts was essentially a churro with Mexican hot chocolate but this is no ordinary churro, it is a decadent foie gras churro. Heaven!
author: Yi Z.

description:
If you have ever wondered if gourmet Mexican food was possible, Californios will make you a believer. This amazing restaurant earned both of its Michelin stars and will truly impress you and your guests with one of the best experiences I have ever had in a restaurant. The restaurant is on 22nd near Mission with little exterior signage near several dive bars and colorful characters. BART is close and a fun walk.

You need to reserve and pay online well in advance for dinner here. I was able to snag an early reservation and was somewhat surprised by the low cost of the meal, although the beverage pairing was nearly as much as the food. At 5:30, I opened the heavy door and entered an upscale speakeasy with an open kitchen. After a greet and check in, I was escorted to the chef's counter to begin my journey.

It is hard to describe the next two hours since the menu changes all the time. The dinner had 19 servings of various small plates, amuses, and cleansers designed to really push the envelope of Mexican inspired cuisine with a gourmet California theme. The beverage pairings included wine, beer, and several surprises which worked very well with the items. Pairing wine with spicy food is a real art.

The food was just spectacular. The scallop chicharron, torched mandarin, mushroom mole taco, and winter vegetable aquachile were very unique and delicious. The fried fish, wagyu carne asada, and smoked squab were true gourmet quality. The macadamia nut sorbet with fresh pear and dulce de leche was both real and spectacular!

It is no understatement to say that the best parts of the meal were the tamale, beans, and churro. Of course the tamale used specially grown corn masa ground for hours into a near fudge consistency stuffed with perfect beans and cheese. The bean dish is beyond words with cooked whole beans topped with puréed and whipped beans and caviar bringing the concept to another level. The churro is made with foie gras in the batter and in the icing and served with a small Mexican chocolate and coffee liqueur cocktail making this signature dish crazy delicious.

Of course, the staff and chefs here are near perfection. Service was warm and personal with great attention to detail. Sitting at the chef's counter allowed me to see the care and skill of the young, fun, and inked chefs having fun watching me savor their creations. Everything was paid online in advance, so there was no bill or any fuss after the meal.

Californios is a fancy gourmet Mexican restaurant that should be on everyone's bucket list. This is an excellent date night place or perfect place to take the parents or guests. It is intimate and fun with a unique and eclectic menu that really forces you to reevaluate your definition of Mexican food. These guys are really cooking up something special in the Mission.
author: Kristian D.

description:
I've only been to a few Michelin Star restaurants, but Californios has been my favorite so far. The food and atmosphere are exceptional and the staff are friendly and attentive. I came here with a good friend and sat at the counter so we could watch the kitchen -- this was an amazing experience and I would love to share it with everyone I know. The kitchen is so thoughtfully managed and quiet, almost zen-like. 

For the price point, this restaurant is probably underrated. I plan to be back regularly and will try the vegetarian menu next time for fun.
author: Erika N.

description: Super accessible "SF chef tasting menu" type restaurant. Ingredients common to California and Mexican staple dishes are combined and presented in a fresh but familiar way. Sitting at the bar the atmosphere was friendly and decidedly less stuffy than similar tasting menu restaurants. Watching each cook and sous chef assemble the dishes, and then having each explain the ingredients and flavors first hand was exciting and a lot of fun.
author: Nick J.

description:
Mind completely blown by a wonderful dining experience that I can only describe as "Mexican kaiseki".  One of the personal goals I set for myself this year was to eat at all of the 33 Michelin-starred restaurants within the San Francisco city limits and Californios was number 30 out of 33. At this point in my culinary journey, I've become really, really picky but I'm glad to report that this restaurant is definitely in my top 3 so far (the other two are Quince and Atelier Crenn).  

What I really love about this menu is that it was incredibly balanced and there was a great respect for ingredients and rhythm to the meal (similar to Japanese kaiseki) while also providing great desserts (to me, the weakest part of Japanese kaiseki meals are the desserts at the end).  Not everything was perfect but the combination of dishes and flavors just work. 

(1).  Canapés included scallop ceviche, crab tostada, black barley chicharron with smoked
goat cheese - served with a refreshing cucumber agua fresca (5/5) - damn good start to the meal.
(2). Taco ensemble including uni (Santa Barbara), A5 wagyu, smoked mushrooms and squab (5/5) - amazingly, the mushrooms easily beat the others. 
(3).  Palate cleanser included guava sorbet with pineapple juice and bee pollen (5/5). 
(4).  The next three courses included kiwi, kampachi ceviche and asparagus with trout roe (3/5) - good dishes but not stand-outs relative to similar dishes at other restaurants in the city. 
(5.). Smoked chicken broth (5/5) - I really appreciate that they had a consommé in the middle of the meal to prepare you for the coming richer courses. This broth was just perfect. 
(6).  Next came their signature dish - tres frijoles with caviar (3.5/5) - the beans were great with the caviar but this is not the most memorable thing on the menu (other restaurants have signature dishes that are memorable like the ridged pasta with foie, black truffle and Marsala at Acquerello or the Kir Breton at Atelier Crenn).  
(7).  White sturgeon grilled robata style with grilled cabbage (5/5) - the glaze on the sturgeon was unexpectedly perfect.
(8).  Lamb with morels (3/5) - acceptable lamb dish but most of the Michelin-starred restaurants in the city serve amazing lamb dishes (the best one I've had was at Lazy Bear) and this was middle of the pack. 
(9).  I ordered the marshmallow tea with chamomile before the sweet courses (4/5) - this was nice and complemented the desserts well. 
(10).  The desserts included churro, strawberries and pecans (5/5) - these were inventive and great and not too heavy.  I would have loved to have gotten some mignardises but I was perfectly content with these three things. 
(11).  The meal started with proseco (great meals start with some bubbly) and ended with some agave (unique and nice touch).  

The outstanding dishes for me were the smoked mushroom taco, the smoked chicken broth and the glaze on the sturgeon.  

Service was impeccable and I am very grateful to have been seated at the bar.  It's like dinner and a show - it was a real treat to see the chefs meticulously prepare each course and chef Will was also very engaging (a treat for solo diners).  The place is immaculate and I really love the upscale but not stuffy vibe of this place.  It's also a tremendous value compared to some of the other restaurants at this caliber (Atelier Crenn, Quince, Benu, Coi, Saison). Highly recommended and I can't wait to come back here.
author: Andrew S.

description:
What a fantastic meal.   Loved it.   There are no other Mexican restaurants with two michelin stars in the county, so it's the best you will get in the USA.   This past xmas, I ate at Quintonil and Pujol in Mexico City, and this is on par with those places.   I would still rank Quintonil as the gold standard, but Californios is better than Pujol imho.

I like the space.   Kind of small, but intimate without feeling too enclosed or claustrophobic.   We sat at the chef's counter which is highly recommended if you are flying solo or a party of two.   I love watching all of the chefs prepare my food.   It's like tv!

The menu was roughly 18 courses, so I will not describe every single dish, so I will hit on some highlights, but all of it was great.

The openers they serve you are a great way to start a meal.   Scallop tostada, some crab and blood orange thing, agua fresca, and some weird chicharron made from barley and some other vegetative material.  All were fantastic.

Next were the tacos.   Once was uni, one was mushroom and one was squab.   It's hard to pick a favorite, but the squab was served with this AMAZING mole dipping sauce that I am still dreaming about.

There was also this kampachi ceviche that was cured in smoked nopales.   There were pieces of the nopales folded into the kampachi, which was thinly sliced and wrapped into a butterfly shape.   The best part honestly was the juice/sauce which had hints of the nopales, citrus and celery.

Asparagus in poblano sauce with roe.   Enough said.

Tres frijoles - This seems to be a dish that never leaves the menu.   Three layers of bean preparations and topped with caviar.   Really great (although cannot top the beans they served at Quintonil, of course)

Carne Asada - wow!   Perfectly cooked piece of wagyu, topped with truffle "mole" and served with a confit aged potato all with shaved black truffle on top.   Really rich and luxurious.

Churro with plantain - Great!

Pear dessert - one of the best desserts I have ever had.   Pear ice cream with dulce de leche served on top of macadamia nut butter.   Divine!


Service, of course, was on point (as you would expect) and the overall experience was impeccable.   The sommelier didn't exactly knock into the stratosphere, but the pairing was very nice and recommended (sorry to keep bringing up Quintonil, but their somm is a GOD, and i can't help but compare every pairing to that these days). 
 Recommended if haute Mexican is your jam and you can't make it to Mexico City!
author: Christian C.

description:
Best meal period hands down. 5 stars really isn't enough. I suppose if I was a more circumspect reviewer I would be able to give this place a truly stellar rating in my repertoire instead of giving it the same score as that tacqueria I was in that almost burned down.

The waiters are extremely attentive, pacing is spot on. I really enjoyed the wine pairings and especially the sour beer pairing with the squab broth. Which, by the way, was so amazing! It was broth + a few pomegranate seeds + cilantro garnish. V nice to sip on.

Anyway, this place is expensive but rightfully so. Recommend coming here for a special occasion and expecting to spend close to 3 hours getting your mind blown by the food.

I also recommend sitting at the chefs counter since you get to watch them prepare the dishes.
author: Andrew C.

description: Sit at the counter where all the action is. Some great dishes, some mediocre dishes. Credit their creativity with the fusion of California cuisines. Personable and friendly staff. Wine pairing pours are unsubstantial, only got a few sips of each wine. I'm happy to spend money on a great meal but in my opinion this place (as with many places in the gentrified Mission District) is catered more towards the tech crowd with money to blow.
author: D. T.

description:
Exceptional experience: service, food, and wine perfection.

I have a friend who is a regular here and I can see why. Their take on food is absolutely amazing. I love the mixture of California produce with Mexican cooking styles, flavors, and techniques. There were many stand out dishes that captured so many different notes in flavors and textures. 

The menu is ever changing, but I believe the taco will be a signature that stays on the menu consistently. It's absolutely delicious. 

The atmosphere here is also less stuffy than the Michelin rated spots. Chef Val Cantu definitely leaves a dinner party vibe. It's black, sleek, and sexy but noise levels aren't so low and energy is higher. Music is high key on point. 

Wines. Get the tasting -- you learn so much and it's quite experimental as Mexican wines starting to take a place in the wine scene. I enjoyed learning as I tasted. They were paired so beautifully. I definitely have to give it up to the somm team there. 

I would definitely go back again. Selfish part of me wished that I could have kept this place to myself. But I'm extremely proud of Californios because they're breaking into the Michelin scene that tends to be mostly French and Japanese rated cuisines. 

I'll be back!
author: Tina Y.

description:
A long overdue review of almost a year! Erick T. and I came here in July 2017 to celebrate our 3 year anniversary and were pleasantly surprised with our delectable meal. The tasting menu consisted of 19 courses and additional palette cleansers, lasting for a total of 3 hrs of your night.

My highlights: pretty much everything. I was really impressed with the innovation and creativity Chef Cantu puts into his dishes. He takes the flavors and ideas of the traditional Mexican cuisine and interprets it in his own way to maximize the purity of flavor and choice of ingredients. For example, a handmade blue corn tortilla taco, ceviche with coconut purée, even crickets!! You know my mouth was still watering for more at the end of the meal.

However, many people question the price point for traditional Mexican food, including me and Erick T. We initially left the restaurant telling ourselves this, but I've come to realize Californios is probably the only Michelin I crave to come back to. I'm a picky reviewer and more often than not, I find myself disliking a few plates of tasting menus. My satisfaction with the total number of dishes is part of my scorecard, and I'm happy to say there wasn't a single dish I didn't like at Californios unlike other Michelins. If you love Mexican cuisine like me, it's definitely worth a try.

Originally a chef at Sons & Daughters, Chef Cantu scored a little spot in my heart. I'll be back again!
author: Christina L.

description:
Made the reservation easily on Tock (after signing up for an account) about 4 days ahead for a Thursday night.  They only had the 5:30 slot but it worked out for us  Prepaid the $157 / person tasting menu plus the 20% service gratuity and taxes.  The wine pairing was $95 extra per person but neither one of us wanted to drink that much so we split one.  There was a slight split wine pairing fee but it was much better as we both got to taste the carefully crafted pairings which truly made the whole experience better without overdoing it. 

We ended up having 14 courses but there was no way we could keep track of the number as the pace was perfect that we never seemed to waiting too long but also had enough time to savor each dish.

The food was Mexican inspired but the dishes were elegant that I often forgot that while I was enjoying the food. 

My highlights:
- Lobster taco, delicately sweet and topped with chili butter sauce.
- Coconut purée with texture that was unbelievably smooth, matched perfectly with a Smaragd Riesling (Austria).  
- Well seasoned crispy fried black cod, moist inside with a great verde sauce.
- A5 wagyu beef from Japan combined with even more flavorful grilled mushrooms.  
- Smoky squab with a duck like flavor but not as chewy texture.  Pure delight.  This was one of my favorites.

The 3 wait staff that circulated and introduced us to each dish were all so knowledgeable about the wines and the pairings were the best I've had in recent memory.   We were 20-30 minutes late due to SF traffic but they were so accommodating that they diffused our stress from rushing.  Loved our 2.5 hour meal and cant wait to go back again next time I'm in town as they change the menu every 3 months.
author: Michael Y.

description:
My favorite tasting menu in SF right now.  

I have been patiently waiting to return during a different season - I don't think it had anything to do with spring versus summer, Cantu has perfected every inch of his menu.  

Truly touched by the note on the table, no celebration, but a handwritten welcoming the return and gratitude for the support.  Started the evening on a high note - never see that kind of recognition until 3-4 visits and a note to commemorate?  Never!

The intimacy is further evident with the service throughout the evening, chef stopped by twice and the dessert was delivered by the brains behind it.

So impressed with the food - innovative and sourcing authentic ingredients from local purveyors.  There were four different types of masa served, all with a regional story and individualized nuances.  The vanilla ice cream was just created by the pastry chef days ago, super smooth and intense, best ever to pass these lips.

Reservations are through the Tock ticketing system, it was just under $600 for two including wine pairings.  Coffee is billed separate at the end of the meal.  Priced fairly for this level of dining and I surmise the cost will go up when Michelin gives them their well deserved second star.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
Wow!!! 

What a meal and what a fantastic experience!

I came here a couple weeks ago and am still wistful of this meal.

My favorite bites / dishes were:

1)  Smoked Mushroom Taco: I used to despise mushrooms and until a couple years ago would pick them out of food. Up until this meal, I was relatively indifferent to these fungi. This dish has helped to start to change my view and taste for mushrooms. Californios' mushrooms were smokey and meaty like beef brisket but packed with umami goodness. I'd stack this taco up against an assortment of the notable meat-filled tacos in the Mission. 

2) Mole sauce: Oh my goodness! The mole had so much depth and flavor. Despite it being accompanied by a wonderful bit of squab and my favorite tortilla of the night (sourdough tortilla), the mole stole the show. 

 I enjoyed every dish and thought the sequencing of the dishes were on point. I also appreciated that amidst the business of the night, Chef Val took the time to serve and speak to a course. All in all, this was one of my favorite meals of the year thus far.
author: Brendan Edwin C.

description:
They knocked our socks off! Top five eating experiences of my life.

No signage on the building, creates a sense of "special" or mystery. Only seats about 30. Noir decor that's visually stunning, it's classy, seductive and again, a bit mysterious.

Service was spot-on, and made some beautiful funky weird wine recommendations that I absolutely loved.

13-courses, I think? We were full at the end but it was doable. And although they don't provide you w/the detailed menu, they do provide the list of course names. Some to mention (all done vegetarian) include: chicharron-beets, calabazita-squash blossom, ceviche-coconut, tamale-black bean, and the fresa-strawberry.

This is expensive. We went for my birthday. Not sure about the grand total but I think it was around $700. Lasted for over 3+hours.

Love.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
Great experience over all.  Service was attentive but not overwhelming, food pace in between coarse was perfect. All the courses are fabulously prepared. Although I think the uni could have been done better.  I think the pine nuts and Alvarado mash is over powering the uni itself but still great.  The sauce of the way beef is too salty but the meat itself is one of the greatest I ever had.  
The foe gra mousse are definitely Special.  Will definitely come back again.
author: Greddyv7 3.

description:
Every moment of this meal was an unexpected delight! We opted for the chef's counter- it was fun to watch them work and being a crew of vegetarian, pescatarian, and cilantro-averse, we always knew when they were making our dishes. 

The food was exceptional and perfectly portioned - there were about 12 courses and I left full but not in pain. It would be hard to pick a favourite dish - they were all remarkable. (Though if they opened a taco truck, I would be there every day.)

Our waiter, Robert, was possibly the best waiter I have ever had anywhere. Charming, friendly, sincere and perfectly attentive. He really made the experience a lot of fun. 

We prepaid everything so it was nice to be to just walk out after and not wait for the cheque. 

It is a small space, so definitely book in advance - you won't be disappointed.
author: Rachel R.

description:
Lovely atmosphere, feels fun and classy with the art on the walls, leather benches, furry pillows, and drake playing softly in the background. 

We made a reservation a month in advance, which you definitely need to be seated. No sign out front which makes it feel even more fun. 

We were served 15 courses- 30% which I would describe as small bites. 2 meat dishes, one I LOVED and was my favorite (the carne Asada), a few standard dishes, and two desserts (both of which were ice cream). 

First, all the food was lovely. It was definitely good with some big standouts. The staff cycle through, and we had probably 5 people come speak to us about the food, including one chef. Some were definitely better than others, and I think this is one of the reasons the meal isn't 5 stars to me. Something was missing... the person they sent over to help us pick a bottle of wine was... less than helpful... my favorite thing about prefix menus is hearing everything exciting about the food and the wine, and I think Californios can step up their game here. 

Maybe it's the fact that I'm paying for $200 Mexican food? I keep thinking about why I wasn't in love with this meal, and I can't really put my finger on it. 

Yes the flavors were lovely. Environment is awesome. Will I go back though? Probably not. I would recommend to a friend with the caveat that it's good, but there are other high society Michelin star restaurants that I think do it better.
author: Steph D.

description:
One of my favorite fine dining restaurants in SF at a reasonable price as compared to other peer restaurants. 

I'm normally not a huge fan of Mexican food, but was blown away by the 16-course tasting menu. Service was also impeccable. 

Portions are on the smaller end, but the ingredients are heavy so I was satisfied by the end of the meal. 

Highly recommend!
author: Christine A.

description: Mind blowing experience for sure! Everything was perfect. The beef cheek and mushroom were amazing and my favorite. They really put in time and effort to find the balance between all ingredients and beverage. I definitely will come back a thousand more times.
author: Zoey X.

description: Would be 5* if it was cheaper :) Great experience sitting on the bar looking at the chef cook, but if Im celebrating my birthday I should have chosen a nice table to match the expensive prices. Very delicately created dishes but lacks a grand ambience. For eg. Acquerello had both.
author: Ashutosh T.

description: OMG, amazing experience!! Must sit at the counter and watch the chefs prepare all of the mouth watering plates.
author: Paula Z.

description:
Fantastic experience and everything that we ate was exceptional. Really bright and lovely flavors along with a very prominent Mexican slant to it. 

Service could have been better especially for 2 Michelin stars but nevertheless an amazing experience. We did the pop up by chef Julio and I really have become a fan of this restaurant.
author: Rohan D.

description:
I enjoyed a great 16 course meal at Californios for my birthday. The restaurant exterior is nothing to look at, but I thought the interior was nicely decorated. The night we dined there, they were pumping in late 90's remixes. I felt like I just walked into my playlist, so that was pretty cool. 

The menu is prefix, so the only thing to choose is the wine. The meal started with a lot of small bites/finger foods, so many that I thought I'd never see a utensil. Each one of the dishes were elegantly presented and featured a Mexican or South American ingredient. I also liked that they treated the veggies with as much care as the proteins, I thought the veggies were the bigger highlight in some dishes. 

The service was relaxed, but definitely professional. The people bringing the food to the table were generally good about providing information about the source of the ingredients and some even provided tidbits about the people who produce the ingredients which was interesting. Only one of our waiters was a bit lacking in that department, only stating either the type of wine or the name of the winery, which we could have read ourself on the bottle. 

The only awkward part was that a 20% service charge is automatically included (we were a party of 2). Only reason this was awkward was that he receipt still has a tip line, so it feels awkward putting $0 tip if you feel that 20% is already appropriate.
author: Angelito R.

description: To call this simply a "Mexican" restaurant would minimize (not that there is anything wrong about the Mexican label) its significance. The experience here was better than the French Laundry in service, food and value. I stopped counting courses because just as you thought it was over - there was more! I had so many favorites it is hard to choose - the wagyu beef with the fermented Peruvian purple potato and Perigord truffle dish was superb - savory, slightly sour, earthy umami - just ridiculous; the wine pairing of old Riesling with the smoked wild mushroom taco - heavenly goodness; the mole with the meat taco was also outstanding. There was certainly nothing remotely bad - everything was at least good - at best unforgettable. What are the experience even more pleasant was the overall friendly vibe from every single staff person - presided over by the amazing chef Cantu. This is an evening to remember, savor and reminisce about for years to come. My dining partner and I had a love affair with the entire kitchen crew.
author: Ludy V.

description:
I started a dinner club this year, and Californios was VERY high on my list of places to try and ended up first on the docket for 2018. I went and there was a collaboration dinner on the menu with a chef from Oaxaca (apparently costed more than what I paid for so I thought it would blow my mind). Frankly, for $230 and 2 Michelin stars, it was very disappointing. I did a 6:30pm seating, and didn't end up leaving until 11:20pm, which was way too dragged out to the point where I was falling asleep at the table. 

The service for our table was pretty bad, as I watched the table next to us that arrived 1.5 hours later finish before us. Some of the food was extremely salty (yet beautifully presented), but there's nothing worse than going to a restaurant of this caliber and having no interest in finishing most of the dishes, especially when its 2-3 bites/sips.

I have been to several other Michelin star restaurants before (Lazy Bear, Michael Mina etc.) and did not think this lived up to it's rating. I personally think there are other restaurants in SF without Michelin stars that are better than this and not a $230 price tag.
author: L.k. K.

description:
Overall: This might be the most underrated tasting menu in SF. The price, staff and overall experience makes Californios a must-do.

Food: 5 stars. I love the intersecting of flavors. The carne asada among many other dishes were delicious! I enjoyed every dish and left full but fortunately not uncomfortably.

Service: 5 stars. The staff are incredibly professional and friendly - everything you would expect from one of SfF's top restaurants.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Really lovely space. I loved the aesthetic and friendly reception. We had a reservation for a table at 9 (two people). We arrived at 9 and were asked to sit in their waiting area. Three minutes later we were told we could have a seat at the chef's counter...and that our table would be ready soon. So we went to the chef's counter/bar (PS the space is small- these areas are steps from one another aka, we should've just stayed put in their waiting area). Already situated at the chef's counter/bar, when our table was ready- like 5 minutes later, we asked if we could just stay there. The hostess said yes. How do I know the timing so well? Time stamp on food photos, duh. First photo was taken at 9:09. 

As the courses were arriving we were asked if we wanted to move to a table. We said no. Midway through our meal we were asked to move our stools over to the middle of the bar "for our comfort." Weird. Shortly after, we were asked if we wanted to move to a table again. I found all of that really off putting. Do you want us to move to a table? Were we being loud/obnoxious/distracting/too close to the food (did my hair fall into a sauce??)/having too good a time? :( 

All of that said, the experience was most definitely EXCELENTE. Food was *awesome* everything was incredible and Chef Cantu (Food & Wine's 2017 Best New Chef aka Badass) was gracious in indulging our absurd questions. He also very kindly took photos with other patrons. Really cool vibe overall- front of the house was super friendly and attentive. My only advice, don't eat at the chef's counter/bar. :)
author: Maria F.

description:
Amazing food, drinks, and service.

I'm not a lover of mexican food but my bf is so I decided to take him here for his birthday. The restaurant is small and I requested seats at the chef counter since other people recommended it in their reviews. They have a tasting menu with 16 courses and we opted for the drink pairing.

The food was unbelievable. I never thought I'd like beans and mole like I do now. Dish after dish was incredible (see photos). Chef Val was at the end of the counter and we chatted a bit with him and the the rest of the staff. Everyone was so friendly and really enhanced the experience. 

Amazing. I see their second michellin star in the horizon. 

Can't wait to come back!
author: Laura D.

description:
Now that 2017 is underway, I can confidently say this was, without a doubt, my favorite meal of 2016. Sorry, Lazy Bear, Wako, ju-ni, and Liholiho Yacht Club. Compared to other famous Michelin-starred restaurants in San Francisco, Californios sort of flies under the radar so I hadn't heard much about them and did not know what to expect.

If you manage to snag a reservation when they open up a month in advance, that's half the battle. Our Uber driver dropped us off right in front, and had I not seen pictures of the exterior on Yelp, I would have never guessed the unassuming, dark building with covered windows was the restaurant.

The staff took our coats, warmly wished us a happy anniversary, and sat us at the chef's counter as my girlfriend requested when she made the reservation. From our seats, we watched in awe as each chef prepared the different courses in perfect unison. We watch enough Top Chef to understand the challenges of working in a small kitchen area and needing to prep multiple dishes at a time with pinpoint precision. You truly get the sense that the chefs are giving each dish their all. When a dish arrives in front of you, you get an explanation of its inspiration, where they source the ingredients, and the techniques with which it was prepared.

What sets Californios apart from the pack for me is how they are doing their take on Mexican dishes - infusing traditionally Mexican tastes with fine dining. You just can't experience this cuisine anywhere else in the city. Each dish was a revelation, and I cannot remember another meal I have had where every dish was memorable and left me wanting more.
author: Olivia V.

description:
This is the best restaurant I've been to. Ever. 

The pear dulce de leche thing is the best thing I've tasted in my life since maybe when I tried ice cream for the first time as a child. The flavor is out of this world.
author: Roneal J.

description:
This restaurant is outstanding. 

I've been to a number of Michelin restaurants before (Manresa, Quince, Arzak, Akelarre, etc) and I can't help but feel like there was something truly unique about Californios. It's easily in my top 3 restaurants I've been to. 

I'll start with the ambience. The interior was small but roomy. There are no more than 5-8 tables inside, as well as a bar area where you can sit in front of the chefs.  The walls have colorful Mexican art adorning them, and in the background upbeat hip hop, rap, and pop are playing. 

The result is a really unique feel - it's casual, fun, and lively, yet still has the professional polish of a typical Michelin restaurant. 

The food was insanely good. They don't give you the menu until the very end, and as a result the entire dinner is a surprise, which I really liked. 

I can honestly say I loved every single item on the menu. Standouts were a wagyu steak cooked in a truffle mole, a crab and herb tostada, a squab soup, a foie gras churro, a make your own squab taco dish, and an after dessert "cherry coke" aperitif. 

But, to be honest, everything was amazing. It is the most consistently good Michelin restaurant I've ever been to - at others I've often had one or two dishes which were "meh". 

The food is also very unique. It can best be described as upscale Mexican, but in a way I've never really had before. This made the meal exceedingly interesting and delightful. 

Finally, the service was great. The staff were attentive, explained things well, and were very friendly. 

The fact that you get all this at a price less than most Michelin restaurants in the city makes this a no brainer. I can't recommend this restaurant enough.
author: Davis T.

description: Wow. Just wow. The entire experience was lovely. A long, deliciously planned and well-executed fine dining experience was our pleasure on Friday evening. Warm, greetings and introduction by the hosts and hostesses, absolutely astounding courses, each beautifully and artfully composed. We dined in amazement, and left feeling satisfied, inspired, and cared for. This is a place I look forward to returning to. They really have the hospitality in mind when hosting people for dinner. Though it is not an inexpensive meal, it is worth it.
author: Jason P.

description: This place received 2 Michelin stars for a reason! Decadent food with even better personable service. I love fine dining sans pretentious feels. This place is exactly that! They even get your name and give you a card at the end. So personalized and thoughtful.
author: Ashlyn R.

description:
Words can't describe this restaurant nor would it serve any justice. Just think Mexican Omakase that is perfected in every aspect! Some of the wildest pairings explain how they earned their 2nd Michelin star. 

The staff and chefs are knowledgeable, friendly and extremely down to earth. Just book your reservation if you can and make it happen! You will not be disappointed.
author: Dana T.

description:
Ok, this restaurant is a one of a kind, truly extraordinary dining experience. It's pricy and darn well worth it. If you have to ask how much, forget about it, you can't go there. Seriously, expect to melt plastic at this establishment, all paid in advance. 
Truly great: can't decide, all 18 bites were delicious
A bit disappointing: not one drop of extraordinary tequila 
That said, the wine pairings were spot on and not any we were familiar with (meaning not California wines).
We were there to celebrate our daughter's birthday and she said she loved it, so that was good enough for her mother and I!
author: Fredric R.

description:
Came here for my birthday. This place is by far and away one of my favorite restaurants I have been to. The presentation, food, ingredients, everything was spot on.

They were also accommodating to my fiance and I when we wanted to be re-seated halfway through dinner due to the men next to us loudly discussing the best way to create tax havens so that they could avoid paying any US taxes at all. Super classy gents...

Anywho, hand down my favorite Michelin star experience to-date.
author: Annette D.

description:
15 courses, 4 hours later. This 2 michelin star 'mexican' restaurant exceeded all expectations. Casually sophisticated through and through. 
Beautiful wine selection. A memorable experience.
author: Debi W.

description:
BLACK！BLACK！BLACK！
Black exterior，black interior，black plates，cool feeling all way through, beautiful food, brilliant service, excellent experience!
author: Mark S.

description:
I went to this place before it got it's 2nd Michelin star.  What a treat.  It's a small restaurant with few tables.  Great ambiance and the staff was outstanding.  We did the tasting menu and the pairings were perfect.

Everything from the presentation of each course to the amazing tastes were incredible.  You should go before it gets the 3rd star and becomes more pricey.  Highly recommend it.
author: Francisco I.

description:
One of the top 5 meals I've had in my life...omgg.
My husband and I visited from Chicago. I booked us a spot for a late birthday present to myself (lol) for a weekday evening, and received a hand-written birthday card upon being seated, which was a lovely touch and just one of the may ways they demonstrated their fantastic service and attention to detail, which would become very apparent throughout the course of our meal.
 
Food: 20 courses. Phenomenal!!! Even their so-called palate cleanser was amazing. The food, from standards including asparagus or carne asada, to more inventive dishes, were mind-blowing. Loved their creative combination of flavors and textures, which always came back to the main theme. Ingredients were fresh and thoughtfully chosen. The desserts were also fantastic. And of course, presentation was great as well. We received copies of the menu in nice envelopes with our names on them -- something I wish more places would do!

Ambiance: Cozy and hip without being stuffy as some fancier establishments can tend to be. Bonus: there was enough light to see without affecting the ambiance -- what?!?!

Service: Service from start to finish was phenomenal. Everybody working here was genuinely friendly, without the air of pretentiousness that, again, is prevalent in some of the higher end establishments. Most importantly, the entire team was extremely attentive without hovering or being intrusive. If we needed a refill, or had any questions or requests, staff would magically appear without us even needing to ask. Their timing is so impeccable, it was almost like wizardry.  

Price to quality ratio: I'm a cheapskate who loves food, so I'm especially picky regarding quality of the food as the prices go up. I would say this was one of the few meals that was 900000% worth the price. 
And did I mention their attention to detail was meticulous? 
Cannot wait to come back next time we visit the area!
Would give Californios 6 stars if I could.
author: Jenny B.

description:
VIBE: Small & Trendy
WHY: Everything.

Everything. And I mean everything, was perfectly executed and delicious here. They totally deserve their 2nd star! Kudos!

Do yourself a favor and sit at the chef's table for an amazing, personal experience. Because the tasting menu is so beautifully done, it's not worth ruining the surprises by telling you more. Birthday? Anniversary? Big promotion? Celebrate it here, you won't regret it!
author: Eve D.

description:
Exquisite dining experience with friendly and fun staff who take the already amazing meal up another level with the witty and fun banter. 

Truly unforgettable and so damn delicious. Totally 2 Michelin star worthy!
author: Jay H.

description:
Took le boyfriend to Californios for his birthday dinner, and he was quite the happy panda.

On the reservation, I indicated that we preferred to sit at the chef's counter, and I was so glad that I did. I always like to see what is going on in the kitchen. All the people in the kitchen were extremely friendly and would react with us. At one point, we were talking about the big game that was going on that night (we kept them updated on the score). 

The food, course after course, was on point. Everything was beautifully plated and tasted as good as it looked. 

Will definitely come back.
author: Carolyn Z.

description:
I'll keep it short and simple. 

Love the decor it's all black room with perfect lighting and let's you focus on the food and your company. 

Food was amazing, service was impeccable and fun. Robert who attended our table was so accommodating and created a divine experience.
It's really hard to find fine dinning restaurants that can make this happen.

The tables have the right amount of space apart from each other so you can really enjoy your conversation! 

Now Let's dive into the food: first bites were so creative and the flavor profiles were on point. In the rest of the courses the chef really showcases the quality of ingredients with a harmonious approach. 
I would tell you more but you should try it on your own .... Beans and caviar? yes please !

I will definitely come back here and enjoy another lovely meal soon!
author: Alejandro S.

description:
Amazing Experience!  Highly Recommend!

This is "a of the top places to go for a 'Michelin Star' experience in San Francisco".  Will not disappoint. 

You'll step into a elegant fine dining atmosphere that provides exceptional and impeccable service.  Seasonal food and wine pairings that will bring you back for each season. 

For the wives out there that don't know where to go for a unique experience for Fathers Day "alone time" ;-D  I highly recommend Californios.   It was truly romantic.  It's an intimate dining experience with just the right amount of tables.  No yelling to communicate!  Enjoyable & Memorable!!

Trust me on this one!  Summer is a long season have a bbq another time.  The boys (golfing buddies) and the kiddos will recover.
author: S C.

description:
If you are ever given the option between a quiet table or a seat at Val Cantu's (chef/owner) counter at Californios, do not pass up the opportunity to watch the artistry in motion as the chefs prepare plate after exquisite plate of modern, Mexican-Californian cuisine.

The 18-course menu showcases the bountiful, seasonal and regional flavors  yet Japanese wagyu and fluke from the Tsukiji Market welcomingly punctuate the menu. The wine pairing is an elegant mix from our local Napa wine country with interesting European varietals. I was delighted that Charlotte Randolph (beverage director/owner) recommended a Riesling from Dr. Bürklin-Wolf, where I've gone on a wine tour during my first visit to Germany.
author: Rosella S.

description:
The meal itself was wonderful, creative, and very well thought out from flavors to textures to presentation. The service was absolutely superb, and the staff definitely earn their 20% mandatory service charge. No complaints there.

The pricing point at $157 per person, though, feels a bit high. Though i understand the amount of work and technique that goes into each dish here that may often go under-appreciated, I still feel that the cost of many of the ingredients still shouldn't add up enough to justify the price point. If it was maybe $30-35 less, this place would easily be a solid 5 stars in my book.

With that being said, this was a special occasion dinner, and I thoroughly enjoyed my meal and my experience here. You won't get to experience things like a carne asada of A5 Miyazaki beef anywhere else, so it's definitely worth trying.
author: Kazu O.

description:
3.5 Stars

Service - exceptional 
Ambiance - romantic, spacious, refined 
Drinks - only beer (limited unique offering) and wine (very robust selection)
Plating - beautiful, playful, original
Food - refined Mexican cuisine through a California lens; while a decent interpretation I felt it was too constrained in flavors and could have been bolder
Quality - top notch, treated with respect and created unique flavor pairings to highlight the ingredients 
Portions - while small, the breath is enough to get you to feeling satisfied

Overall Thoughts

While I do have mix feelings about Californios, they overall showed why they deserved their Michelin star and for that I applaud them
author: Eddie W.

description: Great experience.  Staff friendly and tell you a little about each food and drink they serve you.  We added the food and wine pairing.  17 course meal.  Small portions.  You are full after eating for 3 hours.
author: R C.

description:
Just based on phone interaction so far: five star for customer service
I asked for a reservation on very short notice and they didn't have any room unfortunately but... they called back super fast and were extremely nice and personal.
I will be back and eat the wonderful food soon! :-)
author: FOO D.

description: Service was great. Food was great. When it comes to price I just feel like there needs to be something super special and memorable about the food in order to charge that kind of tasting menu price. A good experience for foodies.
author: Tracy P.

description:
I was really pleasantly surprised by Californios. Unlike some other Michelin-starred restaurants in San Francisco, Californios really stands out, with unique Mexican-influenced flavors and a really creative menu.

They did a great job of incorporating local Bay Area ingredients. For instance, they had a fun spin on a traditional quesadilla that was made with sharp cheddar from Sonoma, chantarelle mushrooms from Northern California, and fermented sourdough tortillas. The final result tasted amazing. 

Another standout dish was the dungeness crab with hach pepper mole. The pepper (native to South America) added some great heat and bite to the chilled crab. 

I'm not usually a fan of tapas, because I always leave hungry. And, at first, I was worried that that would be the case here. However, after 16 rounds of tapas, I felt wonderfully content. 

Each bite was packed with flavor, sometimes subtle, sometimes bold. Pretty much every time though, delicious. 

Highly recommend!
author: Erick T.

description:
This is one of San Francisco's top restaurants. It is pricey, but much better value for that price point than many other fine dining options in the city. Why go to yet another French (or French inspired) restaurant when you can have something more authentic and local: a new take on Mexican and Californian cuisine. 

We had a 15 course tasting menu (see photo), menu changes frequently, but my favorites were the lobster taco and the queso fundido with sourdough tortilla. 

The staff was very attentive and impressive, and the founder/chef Val was really nice and humble. I like how they rotate through the whole staff to bring you each course, including the chefs.
author: Mike G.

description:
How is it possible that I enjoyed this meal even more than the first time? 
This restaurant is killing it and is without a doubt one of my favorite places in SF. The service is astounding as usual, the food inspired, creative, and reflective of its Mexican heritage, and the pairings are still the best I've had in the city. Their somm is a freaking genius. 

Already planning my next 2 visits.
author: Chad S.

description: One of the more unique upscale restaurants I've tried in the Bay. Creative. Variety of masas were fun to try. I think it's more of a Michelin 1-star than 2, but still highly recommend.
author: Keith P.

description:
The Michelin Star that has been awarded to Californios is well deserved. As soon as the first course hits the table your senses are assaulted in the nicest possible way. The restaurant has been billed as a modern take on Mexican cuisine, but I think to most that will be left open to interpretation. I honestly don't know a whole lot about Mexican food, but what I ate here at Californios, I liked. Some dishes were really good, and others blew me away. Especially the dessert courses. Those were incredible. Unfortunately I left the menu behind at the restaurant and I can't remember the names of the dishes for the life of me. Be sure to check out my pictures though. 

As for the service, I have to tell you that I had absolutely no issues. They were attentive, courteous, and explained each course with detail. These guys were absolutely spot on.
author: Mark M.

description:
You're reading the words of an oracle, because I had predicted Californios would receive a Michelin star after enjoying a fantastic meal here in August. And what do you know - one star for 2016! I'm always right.

I came for a celebratory dinner, and was blown away by the experience (and I'm usually the one doing the blowing). The service was formal yet warm, and each dish was impeccably constructed. The flavors were familiar with a complex and refined twist. These are not your average taco truck taquitos. Some of my favorite dishes were the corn with uni, salmon, wagyu and foie gras dessert.

Prices have increased significantly since the restaurant first opened - tasting menu is now $97 per person, which is still a good deal considering the number of restaurants that charge twice as much for food that's only half as good.
author: Suany W.

description:
A food poisoning story. 

A girlfriend and I ate here last night and I'm almost 6 month pregnant. We told them there were few foods I had to avoid (like raw steak tartar, high Mercury fish, etc) and they were accommodating with substitutions. 

What had happened to me after leaving the restaurant, was pure hell from 10pm until 5AM. I had the worst case of food poisoning which involved throwing up over 20 times and nonstop bathroom trips. After 2 hours of cold sweat, throwing up, bathroom, we ended going to the UCSF pregnancy Triage to make sure our baby was ok. Since I wasn't able to hold down any water without throwing it up 5 minutes later. Certain food poisoning result in miscarriages and stillborn so we were super worried and not able to feel the baby kick by the time we got to the hospital. I was so delirious from water dehydration I felt as if I could faint at any time. 

After 5 hours at the hospital, and bags of IV later with anti nausea medication, I was discharged at 5AM and finally starting to feel like human again. 

I thought it might have been just me since pregnant people are more susceptible to food positing, but after talking to my friend, she also had diarrhea as well. So it's not just me. It may have just hit me 1000x harder since I'm pregnant. I would also like to add I never threw up the entire time during my pregnancy and I've also had food poisoning before (so I know what it feels like and this was 10x worse than ever). 

I have my hospital discharge papers if the restaurant need some kind of proof this happened.
author: Jean L.

description: Outstanding execution and a game-changing display of the unexplored possibilities of Mexican cuisine. Pushes the envelope without falling into the trap of technique for technique's sake. Balanced and subtle flavors. Constantly evolving menu. Great service.
author: H S.

description:
Received 1 Michelin Star (2016)

This review is super delayed, since I went to Californios right after they first opened. In any case, better late than never! My friends and I made reservations for a dinner on a weekday night, and were seated right when we arrived. Our menu consisted of:

Botanas, Hielo, A-Chile, Papas, Caldo, Huevo, Halibu, Pato, Horchata, Piña, Dulces

-Botanas/Snacks (Round 1: Oyster w/Nasturtium, Green Tomato Water & Chips and Dip: Yucca Chips, Smoky Goat Cheese, Trout Roe, http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=NL234_IAVqkRBK99-kd8ZA&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): They oyster was super fresh, and the yucca chip combination was very tasty.
-Botanas/Snacks (Round 2: Purple Haze Asparagus & Corn Puff, http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=vlej4TXY1bQ9OnTgQ65ssA&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): The asparagus had a great char and was seasoned well, and the corn puff was crunchy and interesting. 
-Botanas/Snacks (Round 3: Granita, http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=JCkuKsTTiwR2zFf6sy3ICg&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): I'm not a huge fan of granitas, but this version was pretty good, and very refreshing.
-Hamachi Ceviche w/Serranos, Cilantro Blossoms (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=a4UihLsRVjG5KLo-UmrKVQ&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Delicious- the hamachi was super fresh. 
-Poached Potato (w/Dill Pomme Puree, Chipotle Adobo (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=rEie8YLbAp_RKKR5DcjFdA&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg, http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=vC3pjUa9qQYXIUn7S7PKng&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Yum- the puree was very smooth and creamy, and the flavors went really well together.
-Bread (Buckwheat Sourdough w/Flax Seeds, House Cultured Butter, http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=kV7MGTIA52BHZk661F9NUg&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Solid bread and butter combination, and I liked that they toasted the bread.
-Smoked Egg Yolk (w/Peas, Jalapeno Grits, http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=o9q-okzeG4COyrNVTJJAHw&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): The smoked egg yolk added a great richness, and the peas were perfectly cooked.
-Soup (Chicken, Turnips, Herbs, Chicken Stock, http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=gWwm1EWM9NHiCIJN4lBylQ&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Since this soup took 5 days to make, it's flavor was super concentrated. I'm not a big soup fan, so this was just ok for me.
-Poached Alaskan Halibut (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=sDxgDvXH5I8-OPZ-Cx_UgA&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): The fish was cooked very well, and the flavors worked well together.
-Grilled Gerard Farms Duck (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=tl-aYfXuU0MKUVsiiD8vdA&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Flavorful, but it was definitely served on the rare side, even for me.
-Horchata Rice Ice Cream (w/Strawberry Sorbet, Strawberries, Mochi, http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=cphnm2-Ja6l5H5I0qaTz2g&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Not my favorite since I don't like the cinnamon flavor in horchata or sorbet.
-Dessert Part 2 (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=cRHzxw1RrL1LkM4ZvwRIrg&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): I can't remember exactly what this was anymore, but remember the top part was frozen. I didn't think it was anything special.
-Mignardises (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=03NDPY67qobpc1UdBLHlIg&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): I LOVE when restaurants end a prix fixe with mignardises (unless its pate de fruit), and I enjoyed the caramels and cookies, but not the pate de fruit.

Service was great, and we thought it was a great meal overall. They raised their prices right after we went (it was an amazing deal when they first opened) but it's still reasonable for the quality and quantity of food. Highly recommended for a special occasion or fancy dinner with friends. Parking can be tough to find in this area, but there are spots on the street available.
author: Amy D.

description: The wine pairing was spot on, and service was excellent too. Often conflicting tastes create something new and surprising.
author: Noel H.

description:
Amazing service - we came for a birthday and the staff was very accommodating with the birthday request. I initially booked an 8PM spot at the Chef's table, but I emailed the business to move the reservation up. 

We were greeted with champagne and shared a wine pairing along with the September tasting menu which included a lot of beans & fresh fish. The A5 wagyu and salmon were my favorite dishes - however, they are hyper-local and hyper-seasonal, so definitely catch those two items this month! 

We chatted with the chefs during the dinner (highly encourage chef's table) and took a picture with the head chef at the end of dinner. Everyone was so amazingly accommodating and we couldn't have asked for a better time!
author: Jennifer J.

description: i've had an exceptional dining year, and californios was probably my favorite experience, which is saying a lot, as alinea also happened earlier this year. everything was magic, starting from the moment i stepped into the understated and sexy dining room on 22nd street. highly recommend sitting at the chef's counter. interact with those who work there - everyone has really interesting background and wonderful stories and energy to share. joon was really great. chef is understated and humble. what a fantastic experience.
author: Christina L.

description: Love everything about this restaurant. One carnivore and one vegetarian on a birthday dinner. Lovely evening, and the tasty food, great flavors and fast service were all wonderful. Thank you for the great experience! I will definitely be back!
author: Audrey H.

description:
Best dining experience in SF. I asked my gf to take me here for my birthday dinner and it couldn't have been more perfect.

I've sent many people here when they ask where to go for an anniversary, birthday or parent dinner.

This is a fancy restaurant with refined food but they hold the pretension, just how I like it!

Their service is 100. Charlotte and Carolyn (they run this ship) have created and maintained an amazing atmosphere. The decor is fucking TIGHT. So cool and chic and hip. The curation of every single detail is superb. Even the bathroom is chic.

Charlotte is the beverage director and boy, as diners we are lucky for that because I had the most perfectly paired meal of my entire life. When I took a bite of each dish i thought "this is the best bite ever," but then when I sipped whatever drink was paired with it it made it even better! Not only that but Charlotte explained each drink in layman's terms for me and it just made me feel so comfortable and not like I was out of place in such a nice restaurant.

Chef Val is a fucking genius. Or an alien. His ability to elevate and refine Latin cuisine is something I've never ever seen on Earth. Every single dish was from another planet, in the best way. I can still remember the familiar feel every dish evoked. Each bite had that eye-closing mMmMing taste. 

Highlight: birthday bubbly on the house. Made me feel SO SPECIAL! Also, the foie gras ice cream dessert was basically booshy cookies and cream. Best dessert. Best dinner. Best birthday ever.

I'll be back for our next special occasion for sure.
author: Taylor S.

description: I had no idea what to expect coming here on my last trip to the SF. My friend made the reservations on a recommendation from his friend. Previously, two other hole-in-the-wall eateries, this hidden gem shouldn't be passed up!  I had the vegetarian tasting menu and was very pleased!! The texture, flavor and visual experiences were leaving me wanting more. Mexican inspired and very inspiring indeed. I love the fact that they source from local farms as much as possible. Some of my favorites were the bites at the beginning. Highly recommended!
author: Rachel B.

description: Amazing interesting dishes with great flavor. The wine pairing was spot on, and service was excellent too.
author: Ada F.

description:
Unforgettable meal. It was definitely different than your usual tasting menu given it's goal of elevating Mexican food to Michelin-level. 

The three beans with caviar completely changed what I thought of beans. It can be used in haute cuisine.

The salmon preparation was also completely innovative which is impressive how often you probably have salmon. 

The nectarine with a Japanese snapper fish was also very fresh and innovative.

It definitely is a very expensive tasting menu but if you're looking for something fresh and different this would qualify. The staff was very friendly and on point. IF you ask for the chef's counter you get a first hand view at what it takes to make your dishes so beautiful and flavorful.
author: Victor W.

description:
My dinner at Californios was one of the rare meals that wowed me from beginning to end. I can't believe that this place isn't more well-known! 

There is a single menu that costs a reasonable $125 per person. I'd been meaning to come here for the longest time and finally convinced a friend to come with me yesterday. We were seated at the chef's counter and got to watch the magic happen. Is it embarrassing that I kept fawning over their teeny tiny pots and pans? I swear, the stuff that these chefs produced from that small kitchen is nothing short of magical.

The service was very friendly, polite, and attentive. They described each dish in detail as they brought them out - sadly, I didn't bother to take notes because I was told that we would receive a menu at the end of the meal. (spoiler: it's not helpful AT ALL :c )

Our dishes, as recalled by my awful memory:
- Pea Sprout Tostadas
- Agua Fresca with a Shiso Coin
- Fried Pork with Pickled Cucumber Taco
- Fried Fish (?) Taco
- Ceviche with Fish Roe and Avocado
- White Strawberry Helado with Olive Oil
- Yerba Buena (grilled seasonal vegetables)
- Beans 3-Ways
- Broth with Lime
- Sous Vide Egg with Salsa and Caviar
- Monterey Abalone with Tomatillo Broth
- Trout with Tamarind Sauce and Peas
- Sourdough Tortillas
- Lamb with Charred Ramps
- Mt. Tam Cheese Empanada
- Wild Strawberry and Vanilla Flan
- Yerba Buena Mint Ice Cream with Mexican Chocolate Sauce
- Flautas with Dehydrated Apples, Foie Gras, and Crushed Peanuts

Every single dish was outstanding, but my favorites were the pork taco, beans (whipped beans!), trout, strawberry flan, and flautas. Trust me, the beans were transcendent.

This was my first exposure to Mexican fine dining and I'm hooked - I'll definitely be back for another meal!
author: Kelly L.

description:
I like that there's nothing but a very subtle "C" on the door of this place. You feel like you're part of a well-kept secret. We had a fantastic dinner here; almost every course (11 total) was a total hit, but there were a couple misses. Boy was it pricey too--you really have to justify spending like this! Worth it for a special occasion but I wouldn't make this a regular go-to spot.

Once inside, Californios feels like your distant rich uncle's Upper East Side living room, complete with bookshelves and real books. It's dark and it's plush. A little sparse, but they are new and still seem to be finalizing the look (I commented on a gold skull they had at the entrance and they'd just gotten it the day before). 

THE WAIT: None at 8:00pm on a Thursday for four. They don't crowd the tables and give you plenty of room, so even with the large space, there were relatively few tables compared to some restaurants that barely give you elbow room between tables.

THE SERVICE: Great! The staff were friendly, knowledgable, and made the vibe more casual and comfortable (the price tag and the decor would otherwise have pointed to a more pretentious place). 

THE COST: Pricey! $100 for the tasting, $45 for the drink pairing, all before tax/tip.

THE FOOD: There's no pressure of looking at a menu and deciding. The tasting menu is set every night, and they save each course as a surprise (though they will ask about dietary restrictions, allergies, etc). Once your party is settled, the courses start coming out and gradually work their way up into richer, more filling small plates. It's meant to be an 8 course, but you have your amuse-bouche and extra desserts at the end, so the 11 courses works out to a perfect amount of food in my mind.

THE BEST: Huevo (sashimi), Pollo (in farro broth), Sable (swordfish in garlic sauce), Pato (steak), Foie (ice cream).

THE WORST: Papas (custard), Dulces (cookies).

Course 1: Botana (nachos and salsa) - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/californios-san-francisco?select=gFZ3g3UY7Yy3xUQBZDUApA#OH-TTEC7t0MHFYsVUZ8AwA
A bit oily on the nachos, but thick with a subtle crunch, comes unique flavors on top.

Course 2: Hielo (oysters) - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/californios-san-francisco?select=gFZ3g3UY7Yy3xUQBZDUApA#aCy5hb6Cq6e6TgLrVbg4GA
Fresh & tasty!

Course 3: A-chile (celery pudding) - 4.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/californios-san-francisco?select=gFZ3g3UY7Yy3xUQBZDUApA#CtlnT2CR7ZBo9YGS5zGHag
I usually hate celery but liked this! A good mix of salty and refreshing fruit flavors.

Course 4: Huevo (sashimi) - 5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/californios-san-francisco?select=gFZ3g3UY7Yy3xUQBZDUApA#sVGQb9Sd530_DoBtMvhdog
The most fresh sashimi I've had, with great subtle flavors, hints of savory and spice. 

Course 5: Pollo (chicken in a farro-infused broth, with bread) - 5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/californios-san-francisco?select=gFZ3g3UY7Yy3xUQBZDUApA#I6CwqPm5sypOy2rB8ishVQ
bread: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/californios-san-francisco?select=gFZ3g3UY7Yy3xUQBZDUApA#BGn6f1c_0cWycByTyrp1nQ
We LOVED the flavor of the broth, and the chicken was incredibly tender. The bread was thick and grainy but could have been 

Course 6: Papas (custard) - 3 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/californios-san-francisco?select=gFZ3g3UY7Yy3xUQBZDUApA#2VUHvXOBnTTOt-PQkqc8cQ
The least impressive dish of the night. The custard was flavorless and the texture too stiff.

Course 7: Sable (swordfish in garlic sauce) - 5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/californios-san-francisco?select=gFZ3g3UY7Yy3xUQBZDUApA#N1Yo_pQ7T0XkW5ShiVDTbg
Amazingly strong garlic sauce!

Course 8: Pato (steak, with tortillas) - 5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/californios-san-francisco?select=gFZ3g3UY7Yy3xUQBZDUApA#MoiZ2lw1cH_Bqhww3FotVA
tortillas: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/californios-san-francisco?select=gFZ3g3UY7Yy3xUQBZDUApA#E38D8nkrxNdXKJBqLaDiKA
tortillas cross-section: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/californios-san-francisco?select=gFZ3g3UY7Yy3xUQBZDUApA#-quf2HBx78O8FVOwTEL9Kw
Fantastic in all aspects.

Course 9: Verbena (their version of tres leches) - 4.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/californios-san-francisco?select=gFZ3g3UY7Yy3xUQBZDUApA#HciyXd8zfmiJopU_K4CJmg
Refreshing, light, tasty dessert. But the scoop on top is a cream and not ice cream as we thought.

Course 10: Foie (foie gras ice cream, caramelized banana) - 5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/californios-san-francisco?select=gFZ3g3UY7Yy3xUQBZDUApA#gFZ3g3UY7Yy3xUQBZDUApA
The best savory ice cream I've ever had. Texture and flavor all work flawlessly together.

Course 11: Dulces (biscuit, passionfruit, toffee) - 3.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/californios-san-francisco?select=gFZ3g3UY7Yy3xUQBZDUApA#03xm2ODHYFjYrqAaU6CO7Q
Not the best way to end the meal. None of the three cookies were very impressive, but it was a nice free last dessert.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
My party of 4 came on a Saturday night at 6PM and there was only one other party present. By the end of our meal, the place was basically full. This place is tiny and only seats 30 people so be sure to make a reservation. They said the tasting would take 2.5 hrs but we were done in 2. Also, had I not know that this was a Mexican restaurant, I wouldn't have been able to tell considering a number of the dishes were heavily Asian-inspired.

$75 tasting menu, $45 6 wine pairings, mandatory 18% tip. 

-Tortilla chip w/ roe - too salty
-Oyster - fresh
-Asparagus w/ yogurt - i wish there was more of this
-Celery granita with pop rocks - refreshes your palette and definitely gets you excited for the following course
-Smoked hamachi - haven't had this before. twas delicious!
-Potatoes - potato puree, baked potato, potato chip. what a versatile ingredient
-Tortilla - think pupusa with no filling. meh
-Duck + Fennel Salad - duck was cooked to perfection.
-Dessert - easily my favorite part of the meal. 3 courses!
               Goats milk ice cream and citrus - light and smooth. acidity of the citrus cut through the creaminess of the goats milk well.
               Foie Gras Ice Cream - you can't taste the foie gras but it definitely enhanced the creaminess of the ice cream. 
               A plate of bite-sized sweets: cookies, guava gelee, caramel. The portions were so tiny I didn't even feel guilty after

When it was originally $57, it was absolutely a steal. At the current price of $75, it's definitely pricey. At the end of the meal, I was content, which means my guy friends were still hungry so we made a trip to El Farolito 2 blocks away. Overall, excellent quality, but quantity needs work.
author: Lucy N.

description:
This is my husband and mines favorite restaurant in San Francisco. We've been here 4 times over the last 3 years - it's our go to spot when celebrating birthdays, anniversaries, any special occasion really. 

The food is wonderful and the staff are amazing! All of the cooks are friendly and kind and happy to personally answer any questions you have.

Carolyn and Charlotte who run the front of the house are warm and inviting and super thoughtful - they make you feel welcome and comfortable the minute you walk in.

I love the wine and beer list - it's always has something interesting and different to try.

The menu has been different each time we've gone but some dishes that have stood out are a lobster taco, the trefrioljes, and mole.

I recommend this restaurant to everyone.
author: Anna S.

description: I had been looking forward to this meal for weeks and it did not disappoint! From the moment you enter, you are treated with amazing service. The background music was some well thought out 80's and added to the experience. The place is very dark with just a few tables and a bar that faces the chefs. The courses included amazing abalone, crab and avocado, King salmon with a tamarind reduction, tuna crudo on a micro tostada. All 12 courses came out timely with no long periods. Once this place gets into the groove, it will certainly get more recognition. I suggest you get here soon before word really gets out!
author: Lorenzo R.

description:
I discovered Californios via the Eater Map and was mildly curious to see what they had going on there...particularly that foie gras vanilla ice cream everyone takes photos of.  When the opportunity presented itself, my husband and I wandered out to the Mission to give it a shot.

As you may already know, Californios has a set menu of 12 dishes that range from sweet to savory to heavy in protein, but sourced with all local and organic ingredients for $75 per person (the price just recently went to $75 from $65).  The menu seems to change quite frequently in terms of what's in season, so to make this a little bit more meaningful, I'll just highlight some of things we had that night.

Favorite dishes:
- Celery root apple granita with kiwi
- In-house made sliced bread with flaxseed served with a house made chicken stock soup aged 5 days with parsnip and turnip
- Sourdough tortillas with house made butter
- Sonoma duck served with a shiso reduction and pico de gallo
- Foie gras vanilla ice cream served with peanut brittle and banana

All five dishes completely nailed it.  My husband was a big fan of the granita and duck, and I was seriously drooling over the bread and tortillas.  The duck was served Japanese robata style and had a delicious smoky flavor to it.  And let's talk about the foie gras ice cream.  Absolutely no over-the-top foie gras taste, you get a SUPER rich and buttery vanilla ice cream taste instead.  It's pure genius.

Dishes that we were "meh" on:
- Yellowtail with serrano chili oil
- Oyster with jicama
- Chawanmushi with caviar and blue corn tortilla chips

The yellowtail wasn't cut evenly and in fairly large pieces, so it was a little bit more than a mouthful when trying to eat it.  The oyster and chawanmushi weren't over the top, and the caviar on the chawanmushi seemed to overdo the umami taste I think it was going for.

Service wise, Californios did an amazing job with spacing out our dishes in a even way, and the person in charge of the wine program (my husband had the wine pairing with his meal) did an amazing job explaining each glass that was being poured with the upcoming dishes. Sitting at the bar was also a good experience and we got to see how hard the guys in the kitchen were working to put together some beautifully plated dishes.

At $75, Californios is definitely on the pricey side (more when you add in the drink program), and it's definitely not going to be the type of experience where you'll feel like you need to be rolled out of the restaurant from eating too much.  The plate sizing is delicate and meant to give you a solid few bites which focuses on quality and not quantity.  I definitely enjoyed my time at Californios, especially how much creativity and hard work they pour into each dish!
author: Lisa I.

description: I was really pleasantly surprised by Californios. Incredibly mix of local, taste, flavours and fresh food. The wine pairings enhance the dishes without getting in the way.
author: Giavanna F.

description: We really enjoyed the food and experience here. Imaginative cooking that melds multiple flavors in every dish.
author: Romina B.

description: I absolutely loved Californios! If you are going to splurge, this is the place to do it! The food was absolutely delicious, soo fresh and just the perfect amount! They also have amazing wine and beer selection. We did the vegetarian tasting menu (let them know you are vegetarian when you make dinner reservation) and it was incredible! The service is above and beyond as well! We had something very special to celebrate and we are soo happy we chose this place to do it! I would go back in a jiffy!!!
author: P P.

description:
4.5 STARS

*After dinner at Californios*

Me: "Mmmm, I can eat like this every day."
Mr. NSS: "Of course you can, IF you don't mind pushing around a shopping cart with your belongings."

Damn, that got shut down quick.
